se.softhouse.jargo

Class ArgumentBuilder.CommandBuilder

  • java.lang.Object
    • se.softhouse.jargo.ArgumentBuilder<BUILDER,T>
      • se.softhouse.jargo.ArgumentBuilder.CommandBuilder
  • Enclosing class:
    ArgumentBuilder<SELF extends ArgumentBuilder<SELF,T>,T>

    @NotThreadSafe
public static final class ArgumentBuilder.CommandBuilder
extends ArgumentBuilder<BUILDER,T>
    Builder for Commands. Created with Arguments.command(Command).

    • Method Detail

      • required

        @Deprecated
public ArgumentBuilder.CommandBuilder required()
        Deprecated. Commands shouldn't be required
        Description copied from class: ArgumentBuilder
         Makes CommandLineParser.parse(String...) throw
 ArgumentException if this argument isn't given.
 If possible, it's preferred to use a default value instead.
 
 The Argument.toString() will be used to print each missing argument.
 
 Note: If you choose to use multiple ArgumentBuilder.required() indexed arguments all of them
 must have unique ArgumentBuilder.metaDescription(String)s. This ensures that error messages
 can point out erroneous arguments better
        Overrides:
        required in class ArgumentBuilder<ArgumentBuilder.CommandBuilder,ParsedArguments>
        Returns:
        this builder

      • defaultValue

        @Deprecated
public ArgumentBuilder.CommandBuilder defaultValue(ParsedArguments defaultValue)
        Deprecated. Commands shouldn't have default values
        Description copied from class: ArgumentBuilder
         Sets a default value to use for this argument. Overrides StringParser.defaultValue() which is used by default.
 Returned by ParsedArguments.get(Argument) when no argument was given.
 To create default values lazily see ArgumentBuilder.defaultValueSupplier(Supplier).
 
 Mutability:Remember that as Argument is Immutable
 this value should be so too if multiple argument parsings is going to take place.
 If mutability is wanted ArgumentBuilder.defaultValueSupplier(Supplier) should be used instead.
        Overrides:
        defaultValue in class ArgumentBuilder<ArgumentBuilder.CommandBuilder,ParsedArguments>
        Returns:
        this builder

      • defaultValueSupplier

        @Deprecated
public ArgumentBuilder.CommandBuilder defaultValueSupplier(Supplier<? extends ParsedArguments> defaultValueSupplier)
        Deprecated. Commands shouldn't have default values
        Description copied from class: ArgumentBuilder
         Sets a Supplier that can supply default values in the absence of this argument
 
 Note: Even if ArgumentBuilder.limitTo(Predicate) is used, the Supplier.get() isn't called
 until the default value is actually needed (ParsedArguments.get(Argument). If the
 default value is deemed non-allowed at that point an IllegalStateException is thrown.
 
 Note: May be removed in the future if Guava is removed as a dependency
 
 Wrap your supplier with Suppliers.memoize(Supplier) if you want to cache created values.
        Overrides:
        defaultValueSupplier in class ArgumentBuilder<ArgumentBuilder.CommandBuilder,ParsedArguments>
        Returns:
        this builder

      • limitTo

        @Deprecated
public ArgumentBuilder.CommandBuilder limitTo(Predicate<? super ParsedArguments> limiter)
        Deprecated. Commands can't be limited
        Description copied from class: ArgumentBuilder
         Limits values parsed so that they conform to some specific rule.
 Only values for which Predicate.apply(Object) returns true, will be accepted.
 Other values will cause an ArgumentException.
 For example Range.closed(Comparable, Comparable) only allows values within a range.
 
 To override the default error message that is generated with Texts.UserErrors.DISALLOWED_VALUE
 you can throw IllegalArgumentException from Predicate.apply(Object). The detail
 message of that exception will be used by ArgumentException.getMessageAndUsage().
 When this is needed it's generally recommended to write a parser of its own instead.
 
 Note:toString() on aLimiter will replace StringParser.descriptionOfValidValues(Locale) in the usage
 
 Note:The validity of any default value isn't checked until
 it's actually needed when ParsedArguments.get(Argument) is called. This is so
 because Supplier.get() (or StringParser.defaultValue()) could take an arbitrary long time.
        Overrides:
        limitTo in class ArgumentBuilder<ArgumentBuilder.CommandBuilder,ParsedArguments>
        Parameters:
        limiter - a limiter
        Returns:
        this builder

      • splitWith

        @Deprecated
public ArgumentBuilder.SplitterArgumentBuilder<ParsedArguments> splitWith(String valueSeparator)
        Deprecated. Commands can't be split
        Description copied from class: ArgumentBuilder
         When given a "," this allows for
 arguments such as:
 -numbers 1,2,3
 where the resulting List<Integer> would contain 1, 2 & 3.
 
 Doesn't allow empty lists.
        Overrides:
        splitWith in class ArgumentBuilder<ArgumentBuilder.CommandBuilder,ParsedArguments>
        Parameters:
        valueSeparator - the string to split the input with
        Returns:
        a new (more specific) builder

      • arity

        @Deprecated
public ArgumentBuilder.ArityArgumentBuilder<ParsedArguments> arity(int arity)
        Deprecated. pass any Arguments to your Command to Command.Command(Argument...)
        Description copied from class: ArgumentBuilder
         Uses this argument to parse values but assumes that numberOfParameters of the
 following parameters are of the same type.
 
 Integer in the following example:
 
         
 List<Integer> numbers = integerArgument("--numbers").arity(2).parse("--numbers", "1", "2");
 assertThat(numbers).isEqualTo(asList(1, 2));
        Note:If the argument isn't ArgumentBuilder.required() the default value will be a list that contains numberOfParameters elements of StringParser.defaultValue(), in the above example that would be two zeros. If this isn't wanted use ArgumentBuilder.defaultValue(Object) to override it.
        Overrides:
        arity in class ArgumentBuilder<ArgumentBuilder.CommandBuilder,ParsedArguments>
        Returns:
        a new (more specific) builder

      • variableArity

        @Deprecated
public ArgumentBuilder.ArityArgumentBuilder<ParsedArguments> variableArity()
        Deprecated. pass any Arguments to your Command to Command.Command(Argument...)
        Description copied from class: ArgumentBuilder
        Useful for handling a variable amount of parameters in the end of a command. Uses this argument to parse values but assumes that all the following parameters are of the same type, integer in the following example: 
         
 String[] threeArgs = {"--numbers", "1", "2", "3"};
 List<Integer> numbers = integerArgument("--numbers").variableArity().parse(threeArgs);
 assertThat(numbers).isEqualTo(asList(1, 2, 3));
 
 String[] twoArgs = {"--numbers", "1", "2"};
 List<Integer> numbers = integerArgument("--numbers").variableArity().parse(twoArgs);
 assertThat(numbers).isEqualTo(asList(1, 2));
        Note: if default value has been set before ArgumentBuilder.variableArity() is called the default value will be a list with that one element in it, otherwise it will be empty.
        Overrides:
        variableArity in class ArgumentBuilder<ArgumentBuilder.CommandBuilder,ParsedArguments>
        Returns:
        a new (more specific) builder
